items.title: Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland
items.question: What remains of identity and meaning when logic, language, and authority collapse?
items.desc: A descent into structured nonsense where logic, identity, and authority collapse into paradox, revealing how meaning survives not by force, but by play.

items.title: A People’s History of the United States
items.question: Whose interests do national stories serve, and what becomes visible when history is told from below?
items.desc: History from below—power, labor, and the stories a nation tells to justify itself.

items.title: Aristotle's Children
items.question: What happens to the sacred when it is translated into reason, method, and metaphysics?
items.desc: The medieval mind inherits Greece—reason, metaphysics, and the long echo into modernity.

items.title: A Wizard of Earthsea
items.question: What kind of power is possible when self-knowledge, not domination, sets the limit?
items.desc: A corrective to domination fantasies...

items.title: The Brothers Karamazov
items.question: Is love meaningful—or even possible—in a world structured by suffering, freedom, and moral responsibility?

items.title: Cloud Atlas
items.question: Do moral choices echo across time, or does power inevitably reset the world?

items.title: The Dark Is Rising
items.question: How is evil resisted when power must be guarded rather than seized?
items.desc: A quiet myth of inheritance and restraint: the world is held together by memory, limits, and the refusal to dominate what must be guarded.

items.title: Doctor Zhivago
items.question: Can private love and conscience survive when history demands ideological loyalty?

items.title: Dune
items.question: What happens when political power disguises itself as prophecy and moral inevitability?
items.desc: A warning masquerading as prophecy: political charisma, religious certainty, and ecological control combine into a machinery that devours even its chosen one.

items.title: The Golden Compass
items.question: Who has the right to define truth: the soul itself or the institutions that claim to protect it?
items.desc: Critique, fix, and impact: Pullman’s subversion of the epic form.

items.title: How the Irish Saved Civilization
items.question: What preserves civilization when institutions fail: power, memory, or the quiet labor of transmission?
items.desc: The hidden hinge of history—copyists, monasteries, and culture preserved through the dark.

items.title: Les Misérables
items.question: Can mercy redeem what justice alone can only punish?
items.desc: A moral epic where compassion resists institutional cruelty, and salvation is measured not by justice enforced but by mercy chosen.

items.title: The Lord of the Rings
items.question: Is the highest moral victory the refusal of power rather than its conquest?
items.desc: Power, pity, and the making of a world — critique, fix, impact.

items.title: The Odyssey
items.question: What does it mean to remain oneself across suffering, temptation, and time?
items.desc: An origin text of Western consciousness: identity is forged through suffering, restraint, and the refusal to forget where one belongs.

items.title: Paradise Lost
items.question: When does the pursuit of freedom become a prison of pride?
items.desc: Milton’s anatomy of the fall: self-reference hardens into pride, rhetoric replaces truth, and rebellion becomes a prison mistaken for freedom.

items.title: The Wheel of Time
items.question: How does responsibility endure when history endlessly repeats its demands?
items.desc: An epic of recurrence and responsibility: power is dangerous, memory is costly, and salvation requires endurance rather than transcendence.

items.title: Batman Begins
items.question: Can fear be mastered and transmuted into discipline without becoming tyranny?
items.desc: A modern hero myth where discipline matters: fear is mastered, not indulged, and justice is built rather than declared.

items.title: Cloud Atlas
items.question: Do our choices persist as moral inheritance, or does time erase responsibility?
items.desc: The film turns the book’s nested structure into a visual thesis: identity persists as pattern, and moral choices echo forward.

items.title: Dune
items.question: When myth and spectacle crown a leader, can anyone still choose restraint?
items.desc: A visually disciplined epic that captures scale and ritual, but risks mistaking destiny for moral clarity.

items.title: The Matrix
items.question: What do you owe the truth when a comforting illusion is easier to live inside?
items.desc: A pop-metaphysical epic where liberation begins with the willingness to doubt the world you’re handed.

items.title: Mission: Impossible — Dead Reckoning
items.question: When competence becomes the point, what happens to moral stakes and meaning?
items.desc: A relentless machine of set-pieces: precision and momentum are the point, while meaning is mostly outsourced to adrenaline.

items.title: Passengers
items.question: Can love be real if it begins in coercion, even when loneliness feels like death?
items.desc: A romantic premise with a moral fracture: intimacy blooms inside an ethical compromise the story struggles to metabolize.

items.title: Prometheus
items.question: What do you become when you demand origins as entitlement rather than encounter them as awe?
items.desc: A cosmic horror premise collides with philosophical ambition: origins are sought as entitlement rather than awe.

items.title: Star Wars
items.question: What happens to a myth when destiny replaces discipline and familiarity replaces meaning?
items.desc: A foundational modern myth whose later incarnations dilute moral structure in favor of familiarity and perpetual escalation.

items.title: Andor
items.question: What justifies rebellion if the nature of oppression is never clearly articulated?
items.desc: Andor depicts the seeds of rebellion but neglects to describe what's wrong with the empire and why a rebellion is necessary.

items.title: Band of Brothers
items.question: What kind of character survives when fear, loyalty, and death press in equally?
items.desc: A study in endurance and loyalty: character is revealed under terror, and meaning survives through discipline and shared burden.

items.title: Battlestar Galactica
items.question: How much corruption can survival justify before humanity is lost?
items.desc: A political and spiritual crucible: the line between necessity and corruption keeps moving, and every choice leaves a scar.

items.title: Dark
items.question: Can responsibility exist in a world where every outcome is already determined?
items.desc: A deterministic labyrinth: family history becomes literal physics, and the desire to fix the past multiplies the damage.

items.title: Devs
items.question: What becomes of freedom when prediction claims total authority?
items.desc: A clean, cold parable: when prediction becomes total, freedom becomes a story people keep telling to stay sane.

items.title: Fallout
items.question: What is lost when apocalypse is treated as aesthetic rather than existential rupture?
items.desc: It captures aesthetic and irony, but often dodges the raw existential dread that makes apocalypse feel like more than a theme park.

items.title: The Fall of the House of Usher
items.question: What debts accumulate when power is pursued without conscience?
items.desc: Gothic capitalism: power accumulates, conscience rots, and the family becomes the bill that history finally collects.

items.title: The Last of Us
items.question: When the world collapses, does love redeem survival or corrupt it?
items.desc: A brutal tenderness: in a collapsed world, meaning reappears as responsibility for another person—even when it warps into obsession.

items.title: The OA
items.question: Can belief itself generate meaning when traditional myths no longer bind?
items.desc: An odd, earnest attempt to rebuild mythic meaning in modern form—where faith is treated as a creative act.

items.title: The Saboteurs
items.question: What does courage cost when recognition, safety, and survival are all forfeited?
items.desc: A story of covert war where heroism is quiet and expensive: fear is constant, trust is scarce, and duty means risking anonymity itself.

items.title: The Wire
items.question: How do systems designed to survive erase the people inside them?
items.desc: A systemic tragedy: every institution becomes its own survival machine, and people get ground into roles.

items.title: The Wheel of Time
items.question: What is lost when epic myth is flattened into consumable narrative?
items.desc: A grand premise filtered through modern TV instincts: it gestures toward epic order while often flattening the metaphysical weight into plot.

items.title: Dark Souls
items.question: Can meaning be forged through endurance when collapse is inevitable?
items.desc: It refuses comfort and asks the player to endure collapse, learning a harsh kind of clarity through repetition and loss.

items.title: Elden Ring
items.question: What meaning can be assembled when guidance, authority, and order are shattered?
items.desc: An epic landscape of shattered order: freedom becomes the story, and meaning is something you assemble from fragments.

items.title: Fallout
items.question: How do ethical choices persist when civilization itself has failed?
items.desc: Exploration and consequence in a broken civilization: the world is dead, but ethics are still alive and expensive.

items.title: Metroid
items.question: What does solitude reveal when survival depends on self-reliance?
items.desc: A foundational mood-piece: the world tells its story through silence, threat, and discovery rather than exposition.

items.title: Mirror’s Edge
items.question: Can freedom be sustained through motion alone, without a shared vision?
items.desc: A first-person parable of clarity: the city becomes legible only in motion, and flow is the antidote to control.

items.title: The Last of Us
items.question: When love demands everything, is it salvation or damnation?
items.desc: A narrative where survival is secondary to meaning: devotion redeems and damns in equal measure.

items.title: Ultima 5: Lazarus
items.question: What happens when morality is enforced as law rather than chosen as virtue?
items.desc: A rare RPG lineage that treats morality as structure: the player is evaluated by conduct, not just conquest.

items.title: Unreal
items.question: What meaning remains when sensation itself becomes the narrative?
items.desc: A landmark of sensory momentum: tight movement, sharp arenas, and a world built to pressure reflex and attention.

items.title: Wizardry 7
items.question: What kind of judgment emerges when survival depends on preparation, loss, and restraint?
items.desc: Old-school severity: progress is purchased with planning, failure, and the willingness to lose parties to the dark.

items.title: Earth Machine
items.question: How does a planet regulate itself through feedback, and what does that imply about stability and collapse?
items.desc: Planet as engine—energy flows, geology, and the brutal elegance of feedback loops.

items.title: The Elegant Universe
items.question: If reality is mathematical, what do we gain—and lose—by treating the universe as an equation to be solved?
items.desc: Cosmos by mathematics—why the hunt for unity reshapes what “real” even means.

items.title: Out for Blood
items.question: How does exploitation become normal, and what happens when truth arrives too late to prevent the damage?
items.desc: A portrait of exploitation and consequence—how institutions fail, and how damage spreads when truth is delayed.

items.title: PBS Brain Series
items.question: What does neuroscience illuminate about the mind—and what essential aspects does it fail to touch?
items.desc: Mind as frontier—what neuroscience explains, and what it quietly leaves untouched.

items.title: Pirates of Silicon Valley
items.question: When invention becomes empire, where is the line between vision, ego, and conquest?
items.desc: A tech creation story stripped of halo: ambition, rivalry, and the thin line between vision and conquest.

items.title: The Revolutionary War
items.question: How does a nation narrate legitimacy into existence through memory, sacrifice, and selective myth?
items.desc: Myth made nation—memory, sacrifice, and how legitimacy is narrated into existence.

items.title: Fall of Civilizations
items.question: What patterns repeat when civilizations decay, and why do societies fail to correct course in time?
items.desc: A meditation on decline: legitimacy erodes, systems stiffen, and the center cannot hold—until history makes the break visible.

items.title: The World Beneath
items.question: Do intellgence agencies compete against, or cooperate with, organized crime?
items.desc: A descent into unseen structures—how life organizes itself in darkness, and what that teaches about balance and fragility.
